content.body:
Proof: There exist infinitely many prime numbers.

Assume that the set \(P\) of all prime numbers is nonempty and finite. As \(P\) is a finite set of integers, \(x = \prod P\) and \(y = x+1\) are integers; moreover, as every element of \(P\) is greater than one, \(1<p\leq\prod P = x<y\) for all \(p\in P\). As \(y>1\), \(y\) must be either prime or composite.

If \(y\) is prime, then, as it is greater than every element of \(P\), it cannot be in \(P\), and so there exists a prime not in \(P\).

Otherwise, if \(y\) is composite, then it must be divisible by some prime \(p\). It cannot be that \(p\in P\); for, if possible, let it be so: then \(p\) divides \(\prod P = x\), and as \(p\) also divides \(y = x+1\), \(p\) must divide \(y-x=1\), which is absurd. Thus, there exists a prime not in \(P\).

Therefore, given a nonempty finite set of primes, there exists a prime number not in that set, and as the set of all primes is known to be nonempty, it cannot be finite, i.e., it must be infinite.
